abstract.text: A view that merchandises a collection of auto-renewable subscription options that belong to the same subscription group.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A
displays localized information about auto-renewable subscriptions, including their localized names, descriptions, and prices, as well as a purchase button.
Create a subscription store view by using one of the initializers and providing the following information:
A subscription group identifier
A collection of product identifiers
A collection of product values you previously loaded from the App Store

If you provide a subscription group identifier or a collection of product identifiers, the subscription store view automatically loads the subscription data from the App Store, and updates the view when the data is available.

content.text: Provide a background and a decorative icon

inlineContent.text: The subscription store view doesnâ€™t draw a background by default. You can add a background as follows:
To layer a background behind the view, use a view modifier, such as
To set the container background of the subscription store using a view, use the
or
view modifier and specify a
, such as
You can optionally provide a view as a decorative icon next to each subscription option. Use the
view modifier to set a view that decorates individual subscription options within a subscription store.

If you create the subscription store view by providing a subscription group identifier, the system orders the subscription options according to their rank. If the customer is already subscribed, you may want to merchandise upgrade or crossgrade options. By default, the subscription store view lists all the subscriptions in the group. To hide certain subscription options, provide the
parameter in the initializer. For more information about the visible relationships, see

If you create the subscription store view using one of the other initializers, the view orders the subscriptions according to the collection parameterâ€™s order. The view excludes subscriptions that you donâ€™t include in the collection parameter.

content.text: Add terms of service and privacy policies

inlineContent.text: The

automatically displays buttons for the terms of service and privacy policy that you submit in App Store Connect. To override the destination of these buttons with a URL to custom terms of service and privacy policy pages, or a custom view, use the modifiers
and
Use modifiers, such as
, to customize the buttonâ€™s style, for example, to make the text more readable against your storeâ€™s background.
You can show auxiliary buttons in the subscription store using view modifiers. Specify the buttonâ€™s visibility within the subscription store by using the
view modifier.
If you offer your subscription through other services, you can configure the subscription store view to display a sign-in button. Use the
modifier to set the function your app calls when someone uses the sign-in button.
The subscription store view automatically shows a Close button. To override this behavior, use the
modifier to unconditionally show, or hide, the Close button.

You can further customize the subscription storeâ€™s appearance using control styles. Use subscription store control styles to customize the display of subscription options, and how people interact with your store. To try out standard styles, such as
, apply the style using the
modifier.

abstract.text: Create an app with persistent data, interactive widgets, and an all new in-app purchase experience.

abstract.text: The placement of a container background.
A background placement behind the marketing content of a subscription store view.
Specifies the visibility of auxiliary buttons that store view and subscription store view instances may use.
Sets a view to use to decorate individual subscription options within a subscription store view.
Sets the control style for subscription store views within a view.
Configures a view as the destination for a policy button action in subscription store views.
Configures a URL as the destination for a policy button action in subscription store views.
Sets the style for the terms of service and privacy policy buttons within a subscription store view.
Adds an action to perform when a person uses the sign-in button on a subscription store view within a view.
Support In-App Purchases and interactions with the App Store.
A view that represents the default marketing content for a subscription store.
A subscription store control style that displays subscription plans as a picker control, with a single button to subscribe.
A view that merchandises an individual In-App Purchase product.
A view that merchandises a collection of In-App Purchase products.
A view that merchandises a collection of auto-renewable subscription options that belong to the same subscription group.
Creates a view that loads all subscriptions in a subscription group from the App Store, and merchandises them with automatic marketing content.
Creates a view that loads all the subscriptions in a subscription group from the App Store, and merchandises them with custom marketing content.
Creates a view that loads subscriptions based on a collection of product identifiers, and merchandises them with automatic marketing content.
Creates a view that loads a collection of subscriptions from the App Store, and merchandises them with custom marketing content.
Creates a view that displays a collection of subscription options, and merchandises them with automatic marketing content.
Creates a view that displays a collection of subscription options, and merchandises them with custom marketing content.
Present win-back offers to eligible customers in your app with the win-back offer sheet or by implementing custom merchandising.

doc://com.apple.storekit/documentation/S.title: Merchandising win-back offers in your app

abstract.text: Validate your appâ€™s handling of win-back offers that you configure for the testing environment.
A type that represents part of your appâ€™s user interface and provides modifiers that you use to configure views.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
